Speaker: jake
Dialogue: It's the sky, Mr. Plummer.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: It's Camp Jupiter's sky.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Jake! Jake! Hey, Jake! Here!

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Hey hey hey. Look at you.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: What happened?

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Your parents are going to be coming home very late tonight. Come on. Let's go.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I'm thirsty.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: We can stop by Papaya King on the way home.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Yes!

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Listen, Jake. It's your grandfather Max. There have been some... developments.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Some what?

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: I mean, he got sick, and had to go to the hospital.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Sick with what?

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: I'm sure your parents will talk to you when they get home. But I'm going to make dinner for you. What do you want?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I don't know.  What happened to Grandpa Max?

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: When you're old, things happen, Jake. C'mon, let's make the light. We need to get to the grocery.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Hey! Did you finish your homework?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Jardine residence, good evening.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Who is this?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Umm...

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: No, they're not home yet.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Twelve.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: What service?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Hold on a second.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Who is it?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Antonio! Antonio!

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Come! Come here!*

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Antonio!!

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: What were you doing?? If I say `come here', you have to come. Give them a hand. Go.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Hello Mrs. Calvelli. Brian Jardine, we've met.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Of course, Brian. I'm so sad for what has happened. I'm so sorry.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: I'm sorry. Your father was a such a wonderful man.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: He really was, you know.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: This is my son Antonio.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I don't think you've met my wife Kathy.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Hi. Nice to meet you. Leonor.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: So nice to meet you too. Sorry, my hands are full.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: We're having a little reception upstairs. Just family and a few friends.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Ella the Harpy!

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Can you hand that to me?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: She's a nerd, but I have a thing for redheads... Don't you?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Here, pass me that. I can carry it.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Tyson is such a douchebag.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Not in the end, he's not. I just finished The Blood of Olympus.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: I have the game, wanna play?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Now? I'd like to, but... I can't. It's my grandfather's--

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: I know. I never know what to say in these situations.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I think you're supposed to say, "I'm sorry for your loss."

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: That's right! I'm sorry for your loss.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Oh, that's okay.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Wait a minute: what's this one here?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: It's the sky.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Did you make this??

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Yeah, it's the sky above Camp Jupiter, the day of the battle.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: You're a real artist!

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Not really.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Of course you are. This is awesome! You know you'll really like this neighborhood.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: We don't live here. It's just a reception.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: It's become a very bohemian area. You know what bohemian means?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Yeah...

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Very artistic.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: You okay with that, Antonio?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: You can call me Tony.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Well thank you, Tony. I appreciate the help.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Let me see. That was our first year in the house. Look; I still had braces.

Speaker: audrey
Dialogue: Dad looks so young here.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: He was a handsome guy.

Speaker: audrey
Dialogue: Listen to you.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: audrey
Dialogue: You look just like him, and you know it. Can I have this? Please?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Yes. I'll let you have the photo IF...

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: ...you let me have the first edition of The Velveteen Rabbit.

Speaker: audrey
Dialogue: Now, wait a minute.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Do you remember Grandpa's friend Stu Gershman?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: stu gershman
Dialogue: Look at you, all grown up now. How's school?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: stu gershman
Dialogue: So, what kind of sports do you like to play?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: He likes to draw and paint.

Speaker: stu gershman
Dialogue: So you'd like to be an illustrator when you grow up?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: stu gershman
Dialogue: Well, come here. Come here.

Speaker: stu gershman
Dialogue: I want to tell you a few things about your grandfather, Jake: he liked to play ball but was a horrible pitcher; he hated summer but went nuts seeing the ladies walk by in mini-skirts; and he was the most loyal friend you could have. Loyalty was his greatest quality.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Aww... Thanks, Stu. Did you hear that, Jake?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: It's a dessert we make for special occasions in my country.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: I hope you like it.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Oh my God. You didn't have to.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Max loved this cake, so I thought....

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Come in. You should come in.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: It's okay.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Please. I insist.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: No, I just wanted to bring the cake.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Sorry if we didn't say anything earlier. Brian and I... we're both very tired. It's all been so fast.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: It's okay. I still have some paperwork to do at the store.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Thank you so much for this. It's very kind of you. Thank you.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I swear B, I'm surprised at you. I sit there waiting for you to wake up, but everything's great with you.

Speaker: suzanne
Dialogue: No, everything ain't great with me.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: No?

Speaker: suzanne
Dialogue: No. But I got other worries.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Why? What other worries you got?

Speaker: suzanne
Dialogue: When am I gonna be a wife again, Eddie?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I ain't been feeling good. They bother me since they came.

Speaker: suzanne
Dialogue: It's almost three months you don't feel good. It's three months, Eddie.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I don't know, B. I don't want to talk about it.

Speaker: suzanne
Dialogue: Nice! Okay.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: You go "you don't like me, heh?"

Speaker: suzanne
Dialogue: Yeah, I need a break.

Speaker: deborah
Dialogue: Take a break, Suzanne.

Speaker: suzanne
Dialogue: I'm starving. I've been here since ten.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: suzanne
Dialogue: How's Kathy?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: She's good.

Speaker: suzanne
Dialogue: And your son?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Jake. He's great. He's in seventh grade already.

Speaker: suzanne
Dialogue: Oh my God, I remember him running around backstage at The Lortel, when we did...

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Dark Rapture?

Speaker: suzanne
Dialogue: Yes! How old was he?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Two. Three, maybe.

Speaker: suzanne
Dialogue: Time flies by.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: It really does.

Speaker: suzanne
Dialogue: Well, it was great to see you.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Great to see you also, Suzanne. Maybe we'll see each other again soon.

Speaker: suzanne
Dialogue: I hope so.  Jamie? Do you have lunch for me?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: She fucking hates me.

Speaker: roger
Dialogue: She doesn't hate you.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Ever since B.U. She dropped out - I stayed and graduated. Every time we've seen each other since then, she always tries to prove that she's better than me.

Speaker: roger
Dialogue: You're paranoid. You did okay there.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Did I?

Speaker: roger
Dialogue: Yes. But it's true that she'll have a say in who's cast as her husband.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I'm telling you. She doesn't like me. I'm in a slump, Roger. You need to help me here.

Speaker: roger
Dialogue: Listen, maybe Broadway is not the right way to go for you right now.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I thought that was the strategy.

Speaker: roger
Dialogue: Why don't we go have some coffee? You have options. There are a bunch of things that could pan out. Let me just finish this.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: I don't remember this.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Oh my God. We took it home.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Leonor.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Hi Kathy. The boys are in my office, in the back.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: No, no. Look what I just found.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: It's my plate.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: I think that night we just ended up taking everything back to our apartment. And then we put things away, and I forgot. I'm so sorry.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: No worries! Please.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: It's a beautiful plate.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Are you not working today?

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: I don't see patients on Monday. I need a day a week to organize my life, you know.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Good for you.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: The store looks cute.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Huh... we're not doing so well.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: I like that dress over there. The one with the floral patterns.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: I love that one. You should try it on.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: I have to go back-

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Oh, c'mon. It'll take a minute.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Perfection.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Are you sure? I don't know.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: It looks great. All you need is a little fixing up here, maybe a tiny bit tighter here on the waist. But the dress is beautiful.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: How much is it?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Whatever the price, I'll give you ten percent discount. Let me see.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Did you make this?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: No. Not this one. But everything here is handmade by the designers. This one is two hundred and fifty. It's made by a woman named Talita - she's from Colombia, and very talented. They probably do it in their kitchens, you know what I mean? They're not famous. Yet.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Guys, what do you think?

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Jake? Jake, what is our deal?

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: They're like zombies when they start playing these games.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Mom. I'm on vacation!

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: So?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Dad said it was okay.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: We have this rule in the house; no games during the week. And no internet before five either.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: But during vacation they have all this free time, and what are you going to do?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Shhh! Quiet!!

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Antonio! Watch your tone of voice, por favor!

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Mrs. Jardine. Maybe you will let us finish this level, please?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: That's better.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Sure, you can finish. But first you have to tell me: what do you think? The dress?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Great. I actually thought it was yours.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Jake?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Love it. Love the flowers.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Why don't you come help me prepare dinner?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Where's Mom?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Your mother had an emergency with a patient. She's going to be late tonight.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Another suicide?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Jake!

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Dad, I can't find my drawings.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: What drawings? Help me cut these.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: The series I made on Percy Jackson. The sea of monsters?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Those old drawings?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Did you look in the trunk?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Yes, Dad. I looked. They're not there.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I don't know, Jake. Maybe they got thrown away.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Why would you do that? They're my drawings!

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Why don't you just make new ones.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: New ones are never like the old ones!

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Jake. We moved. We got rid of furniture. We threw away clothes, and we gave books away. We have a new apartment.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: So?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Listen. Let me tell you something. It's good to get rid of stuff. It's hard at first, but then it feels really good. You have to learn to let go.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I play Trigorin. He's a celebrated writer, and the boyfriend of a famous actress, Arkadina.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Why the weird names?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Can I finish? Her son Konstantin is an aspiring writer who lives with his uncle Sorin in this dacha, where they all come together one summer to see his new play.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Finished?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: That's just the beginning, actually.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: What's a dacha?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: A dacha is like a big country estate in Russia. That's where the whole thing takes place, and that's why the funny names. There's also Nina. She's the neighbors's daughter, who wants to be an actress. At first she seems to be in love with Konstantin but ends up having an affair with my character, Trigorin.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Sounds complicated.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Well, it is complex. And unexpected. But it has a lot of humor in it too.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: What part?

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Good. You guys are already eating.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Hi Mom.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: How was it?

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Fine. She's doing okay. The problem now is her husband.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: But the last thing I want to do right now is talk about work. I'm starving.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I was just telling Jake about the play.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I thought you weren't working with the Terrain anymore. I thought you were going to do Broadway now.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: It's not that simple.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: You said you weren't doing this non- profit stuff anymore. That the strategy was to reach "a wider audience".

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Well, things have changed.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Jake, you should applaud your father for being adaptable. That's what life is all about.

Speaker: umar
Dialogue: Tony! Hey! Come play! We need one more here!

Speaker: joey
Dialogue: Oops! Watch out, Katy Perry!

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Eight minutes and twenty three seconds!

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Hey! Hey! Hey!

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: A new record! Around the block and up the stairs in eight minutes and twenty three seconds!

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Wow, I think you should call the Guinness Book.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: That's a great idea! I'll write them an email.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Good evening, Mrs. Calvelli.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Hi Jake.  You haven't said hello, Mister!

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Hello Hernn. This is my friend Jacob Jardine. But we call him Jake.

Speaker: hernn
Dialogue: Hello there, Jake.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: He used to live in Manhattan, but now he lives above Mami's store. Jake, this is Hernn.

Speaker: hernn
Dialogue: Ah! So you are the Grandson-

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Yes. Max was his grandfather. His father is Brian Jardine, the one that I told you about.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: My father's an actor. And my mom is a psychotherapist.

Speaker: hernn
Dialogue: I see. So how do you like Brooklyn so far?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I like it a lot. It's more peaceful than Manhattan, and we have much more space. It's great.

Speaker: hernn
Dialogue: So Jake, are you going to be an actor, like your father?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: hernn
Dialogue: But you look like an artist yourself. With that long hair and everything.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Maybe.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: He'll tell us more later, right Jake? Go ahead.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Is your father any good at acting?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I don't know. Maybe.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: I thought if he was, I might have a conversation with him, cause I'm going to be an actor when I grow up. Maybe he can give me some pointers.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Sure, yeah. I guess. He's not that successful or anything.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: My dream is to go to the LaGuardia High School for the Performing Arts? You know that school? Nicki Minaj went there. And Al Pacino, but heflunked out.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I think my dad applied there.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Really? It's my dream school. I'm looking around at some theater classes, and practicing on my own, so I can audition next year for ninth grade.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: But I'm not an actor.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: That's okay. You can read, can't you? Here look at this. This is a scene from Pariah, or the Outcast, by August Strindberg. It's perfect for us to work on, cause it's just two guys.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: And you know what, if you practice your drawing more, and get better, maybe we could both go to LaGuardia. It's for all kinds of artists. It's very Bohemian.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I guess I can try.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: That's the spirit.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Is Hernn your mom's boyfriend?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Hernn? Eww, gross. No. He's just a friend of her's from Chile. My mom is still married to my dad. They just don't live together much.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I don't understand.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Me either! My dad travels a lot, so they are never together. He's a nurse, and he works for Doctors Without Borders, which is from what I can tell a job you get if you want free plane flights.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Where is he now?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: He's in Angola. That's in Africa. Until he was 20 he never left this neighborhood, and then once he left he barely ever came back. If I wasn't here I don't think he'd ever come back to Brooklyn.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Look what he sent me.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Do you miss having him around more?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: At first I did. But it's been a few years now, so I got used to it.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Sometimes my dad goes away, if he's shooting a movie. But it hasn't really happened in a while.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Maybe he's not the guy I should talk to.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I don't know. He's been in a bunch of plays and stuff.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Found it!

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: My dad and I are going to go on a safari, and these are just like some of the animals we are going to see.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Do you wish they still lived together?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Sometimes. When my dad comes to visit, he'll cook Porcheta. It's like roast pork butt.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Ewww.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: We sit at the table just the three of us, and he tells stories about his work and the places he's been, and stories about the different people he's met in Africa. Then it seems like normal. But then, pretty soon they start fighting about something stupid. And I realize it's better when he's not around.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Imagine if your mom goes with you on your safari, and they end up falling in love again.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: I think there's very little chance of that happening.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: But just imagine: you get an envelope one day. You open it and it's two tickets to a safari. One for you, and one for your mom. And she decides to go, because she feels like she needs a vacation. So when you get to Africa, your dad picks you both up at the airport, and takes you to this incredible place. Like this photo here. You see lions and elephants, giraffes. And then, it's the end of a beautiful day in the African savannah. Your dad wants to take you up this big hill to see the sunset, but you're too tired, so you tell your parents you're going to rest in your hotel room.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: So they go the two of them alone. And when they get there, the colors of the sky are like nothing they've ever seen before...

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: A green sky with yellow stars...

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Who wants pasta primavera?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Yes!

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Mami, can I stay for dinner with the Jardine's?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Tony...

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Please Mami. They're having hamburgers.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: And hot dogs.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: We have dinner at home. Besides, I can't come and pick you up later. And I don't like you walking home alone at night.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: He can sleep over.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Have you talked to your father about this?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: He won't mind.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Are you sure?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Please, Mami.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Dad!

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Yes, Jake?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Can Tony sleep over tonight?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Well, hello Leonor.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Sorry to interrupt, Brian.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: No, please, you're not... You've met my sister Audrey, haven't you?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Yes, of course.

Speaker: audrey
Dialogue: Hi Leonor. Long time no see.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Jake is asking if Tony can stay for dinner-

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: And a sleep-over!

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Yes, because after dinner it would be too late for him to walk home alone.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Tony, do you want to have hamburgers and hot dogs with us tonight?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Yes!

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Done deal, bro.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: I just wanted to make sure with you...

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Please. I can't tell you how happy I am that Jake has a new friend. He spends too much time alone. And it's not easy for him with other boys. So it's great that he and Tony get along so well.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: You've got a great kid, but I guess you know that.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: audrey
Dialogue: Leonor, do you want some wine?

Speaker: audrey
Dialogue: Brian and I wanted to have a talk with you anyway, about some things, so maybe this is a good time.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: No, thank you. I have to go back and finish some stuff at the office.

Speaker: audrey
Dialogue: We'd love a minute with you if that's ok. Right, Brian?

Speaker: audrey
Dialogue: Liam, watch out! Your cousin is smaller than you!

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: I have to go. But thank you.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: You know, Leonor, after my father died, there was so much to do. We decided to move in, and time just flew by. You and I haven't really had a chance to talk about the store, and all that stuff. Maybe we can have a chat this week?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: This week is not good for me. I'm doing inventory.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Next week?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Could be.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Thursday I finish rehearsal early, so I could come by early afternoon.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Great.

Speaker: audrey
Dialogue: Truth is, the neighborhood is changing and that's a very old- fashioned store.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: C'mon guys! The burgers are getting cold.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: She complained to me that business wasn't so good.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Of course she's going to say that. Contract is up.

Speaker: audrey
Dialogue: My guy told me that a similar space in the area is going for five thousand.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: What??

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Can I have mine with cheese, mustard and ketchup, please?

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: That's crazy.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Guests first. What do you want on yours, Tony?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Cheese, onions, avocado. And ketchup, please.

Speaker: audrey
Dialogue: That's in the low numbers.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: And mayonnaise.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Scary.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Jake, have some salad also.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I'll have some afterwards.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Tony, salad?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: No thank you, Mr. J. Is that alright if I call you that?

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: And what is the number now?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Sure, Tony. That's fine.

Speaker: audrey
Dialogue: One something. For eight years, never an increase.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Maybe we should talk about this later?

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: So Tony, I hear your dad lives in Africa.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: In Angola. It's an old Portuguese colony in Africa. I wrote a paper on it last year at school, and got an B plus, which was pretty good, cause I only spent about an hour on it. Sometimes at my school the teachers are whack cause they give you good grades for the things you don't try hard on, and bad grades for the things you do.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Can you pass the ketchup, Mr. J? I've always liked a lot of ketchup.

Speaker: linda
Dialogue: Hi, can I help you guys?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: We're here for the acting class.

Speaker: linda
Dialogue: We have quite a few. Do you mean the Breakthrough Class?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Yes. That one.

Speaker: linda
Dialogue: Well, it's twenty dollars for the first class. But you can buy a package of twenty classes for three hundred.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Got cash, buddy?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Oops, sorry. Hmm. What's your name?

Speaker: linda
Dialogue: My name is Linda. What's yours?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Tony. And this is my friend Jake.

Speaker: linda
Dialogue: Hi guys.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: What is your sign?

Speaker: linda
Dialogue: My sign?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Of the zodiac. But no. Let me guess.

Speaker: linda
Dialogue: Go ahead.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: You're a Leo.

Speaker: linda
Dialogue: How did you know??

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Leos are very confident. You seem very sure of yourself.

Speaker: linda
Dialogue: Wow. I'm impressed.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Linda, I'm going to be honest with you. My friend and I heard this place was the best acting school in the area, and we would love to check it out. To see if we want to make the investment. Can you make us a discount?

Speaker: linda
Dialogue: Like I told you. If you buy a package of twenty, you get a discount.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: They also say Leos are very generous.

Speaker: linda
Dialogue: Comes down to fifteen bucks a class.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Well maybe you can help with something else.

Speaker: linda
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Maybe you can give me some directions?

Speaker: linda
Dialogue: Where to?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: To your heart.

Speaker: linda
Dialogue: You're too much. Go in. But only this time. And don't tell anyone.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Thank you, Linda. You won't regret it!

Speaker: linda
Dialogue: Down the hall to the last door on the right.

Speaker: acting teacher
Dialogue: The first thing is to really look at somebody, and just talk and listen, listen and talk.

Speaker: acting teacher
Dialogue: Does that make sense?

Speaker: acting teacher
Dialogue: Okay, let's begin.

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: You're wearing a pretty shirt.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: I'm wearing a pretty shirt.

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: You're wearing a pretty shirt.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: Do you like my shirt?

Speaker: acting teacher
Dialogue: NO! No questions. Observations. Let's start again.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: You have a little nose.

Speaker: acting teacher
Dialogue: Quiet! Concentrate.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: You have a little nose.

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: I have a little nose.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: You have a little nose.

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: Alright, I have a little nose.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: You have a little nose.

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: I have a little nose.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: You seem a little bothered.

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: I seem a little bothered.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: Yes. You seem a little bothered.

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: You're getting a kick out of that.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: I'm getting a kick out of that.

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: Well don't get offended.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: I'm not getting offended.

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: You are acting like a baby.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: I'm acting like a baby.

Speaker: acting teacher
Dialogue: Ok. Ok. Stop. That was okay. It could be better. Yes? Back to your seats.

Speaker: acting teacher
Dialogue: You. Look at me. Don't move.

Speaker: acting teacher
Dialogue: Stand up.

Speaker: acting teacher
Dialogue: We've got to keep the contact. We've got to keep the repetition. The contact comes from my behavior. Not just what I say, but what I do.

Speaker: acting teacher
Dialogue: Look at me. Now tell me something you observed on your way here today.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I almost fell.

Speaker: acting teacher
Dialogue: You almost fell.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I almost fell crossing the Parkway.

Speaker: acting teacher
Dialogue: You see he didn't do it. What was I saying?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I'm sorry I don't understand.

Speaker: acting teacher
Dialogue: You don't need to understand. Acting is not understanding. It's feeling. It's reacting. Does that make sense? Look at me. Listen to me.

Speaker: acting teacher
Dialogue: What did I say without words? What did my behavior say? Now say it again.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I'm sorry, say what again?

Speaker: acting teacher
Dialogue: That you fell.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: You want me to say again that I fell?

Speaker: acting teacher
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: With words?

Speaker: acting teacher
Dialogue: Yes, with words!

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I almost fell on my way to class today.

Speaker: acting teacher
Dialogue: You fell on your way to class today.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I almost fell on my way to class today.

Speaker: acting teacher
Dialogue: You fell on your way to class today.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: You're not listening to me.

Speaker: acting teacher
Dialogue: I'm not listening to you.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: You're not listening to me.

Speaker: acting teacher
Dialogue: I'm not listening.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: You're not listening.

Speaker: acting teacher
Dialogue: I'm not listening.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: You're not listening.

Speaker: acting teacher
Dialogue: Good! That's it. Good. Do you all see the difference? Yes?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Hey, I know you from St. Grace, right?

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: Yeah, I used to go there. I go to Humanities Prep now, in Manhattan.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Oh, la di da.

Speaker: eva
Dialogue: We all went to St. Grace. There were some crazy people in that school. Julia, you remember Mr. Clay?

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: How could I forget Mr. Clay? That hair!

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: Three hairs came from the bottom in the back and somehow they ended spreading like a wig in front. Does he still do it?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Yeah. Only difference is now that he's older, he does it with two hairs, instead of three.

Speaker: eva
Dialogue: I never even noticed his hair.

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: How could you not?

Speaker: eva
Dialogue: Mr. Clay was the first love of my life. I was completely obsessed with him.

Speaker: all
Dialogue: Eeeewwww!!!

Speaker: eva
Dialogue: I used to fantasize about kissing him all the time.

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: Gross!

Speaker: eva
Dialogue: Did you ever see his body? Hello?? He used to play volleyball with us. In the summer he'd take his shirt off. He was as hairy as an ape. I loved it.

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: So Jake, you were pretty good in class today. That was a tough exercise.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Jake's going to be an artist when he grows up.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: Are you? What's your medium?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I paint, but you need to have something special to be a painter, and I'm not so sure I've got it.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: You just need to believe in yourself a little bit. That's all.  My friend has a little problem with his confidence. But we're working on that. Right, Jake?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Hey, who wants to do the repeat game with me? I need to practice.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: Who wants to do the repeat game with me?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: No questions!!

Speaker: eva
Dialogue: No questions!!

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Look at me! Listen to me! Acting is not understanding! You don't need to understand. Does that make sense? Yes? Yes? Yes?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Hey Umar, you should try that thing that the Brazilian does, Felipe Melo. You look to one player but you pass the ball to the other side.

Speaker: umar
Dialogue: We could try it if you played with us more often.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: I don't know what you're talking about.

Speaker: umar
Dialogue: You didn't show up last Saturday.

Speaker: joey
Dialogue: It's because Tony has a new boyfriend now!

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Yeah, ask your sister if she thinks I'm the type to have a boyfriend. She knows.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: So what?

Speaker: joey
Dialogue: That's his school, isn't it?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: What are you talking about?

Speaker: umar
Dialogue: Roller girl.

Speaker: joey
Dialogue: Little Jake. My cousin goes to his school. They say he's a weirdo.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Shut up, Joey!

Speaker: joey
Dialogue: My cousin says he draws dresses for the girls during recess.

Speaker: joey
Dialogue: Hey! Give that back to me!

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: There you are. Eat it.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Give that back!

Speaker: bianca
Dialogue: Can I help you?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: No thank you.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Hi Leonor.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Wait, wait. Where do you think you're going?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Is Tony in the office?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: He is, and he's staying there. He's helping me out today.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: But we're supposed to meet some friends.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Are those the same friends that beat him up?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: What??

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: That's right. They beat him up. You should ask him why.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Hey.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: What happened??

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Nothing. I bumped into Joey at soccer.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: But your mom--

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: She's so dramatic, she deserves an Academy Award. She doesn't want me to go out so I can help her with this. Look.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: She's terrible with numbers, you know. You go ahead. I'll come find you as soon as I finish here.

Speaker: nina
Dialogue: What are you writing?

Speaker: arkadina
Dialogue: Boris! Where are you?

Speaker: arkadina
Dialogue: We are not going away, after all.

Speaker: nina
Dialogue: It is a dream!

Speaker: director
Dialogue: Okay. Let's try this one more time. And Brian, when you mention the dead seagull, don't look away from Nina.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: More seductive, you mean.

Speaker: director
Dialogue: Exactly. You're very myopic. You have an obsession with the details of things, of people. And in this scene you're fully focused on Nina. You're like a razor beam.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Brian. I was waiting.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I'm so sorry. Rehearsal went later than I expected. Is this still a good time?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Yes. I sent the girl home early so we could talk. You want to go inside? I'm just going to finish this.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: The store looks nice.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Thanks. I did a lot of work here.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: The reason why I'm here, Leonor...

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Your lease has been expired for more than six months now. I guess you guys were about to renew it when my father passed?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Brian, why don't you sit down.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: My sister and I are working on the transfer of ownership for the house. It's almost done; Dad left everything in order, all the taxes paid and all that. The only thing still pending is the store, which needs to have a new lease.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: You know, your father never thought much about contracts. He was very happy to have me here. Max thought my store gave "glamour" to the neighborhood, and he was proud to be associated.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: The situation has changed, and now we have two families owning the house; mine and Audrey's. It's better for us, and for you, to have things done the right way, wouldn't you agree?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: It depends on what the right way is for you.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Leonor, this neighborhood is changing very fast. The rents have gone up quite a lot in the past few years. I'm sure you've noticed.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Yes, I noticed and so did Max. But it was his desire that I stay here.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: We don't want you to go away. My sister Audrey has prepared a new lease for you, and we think it's very fair. We aren't trying to get market rate here, we know that's not possible, but still, you can't expect to pay the same rent you paid when you first moved in.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Here, why don't you take a look.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Before we go any further with this conversation, I want you to take a look at this.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: I am probably the last person to have photos printed, the old fashioned way. It's completely different than seeing them on a cellphone, don't you agree?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: That's me in the backyard, on July 4th. That's me and Tony and your father at the Fair of St. Anthony's. That's us with my family, when they were visiting. Your father and I were very good friends. We spent a lot of time together. What you and your sister don't understand is that Max wanted me to stay here. He thought of me as part of this house, this neighborhood.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: I was more his family, if you want to know, than you were.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: That's a ridiculous thing to say.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: You hardly talked to each other. You never came to visit. I was the one here. I saw him everyday.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: This is not what I came here for. Why don't we go back to the lease. Take a look, please. It's fair.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: No, I don't need to. I have an idea what you and your sister have in mind. I'll just give this to my lawyer because, to be honest with you, Brian, I'm not sure I owe you anything. Maybe it's the other way around.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Well, I guess there's not that much more to be said then.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Goodnight, Leonor.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Brian. Want to help me out here?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Sure, but just give me a moment.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: What's wrong?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Hi Dad!

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Hi, Mr. J.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Jake, you know it's a weekday. What are you doing playing video games?!

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Can Tony stay and eat with us?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Why not? He wanted to ask you about your acting career.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: That's enough for tonight. Turn it off.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Dad, c'mon!

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I said no.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: We're about to finish the level.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Tony, you need to go home now. We can talk about acting another time.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Sure, Mr. J.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I'm sorry, buddy. Your mother is waiting for you downstairs.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Did you ask your mother?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: She loves when Jake comes over.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Please, Mom? Please?

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Jake I just made dinner.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I'll eat it tomorrow for lunch, I promise.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Okay. But I want you back here in the morning.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Yes! Thanks.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Thank you, Mrs. Jardine.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: No, Antonio.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: C'mon, Mami. We have spaghetti in the fridge.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: When I say no I mean it. Don't ask me again.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: But we're going to be super quiet! Aren't we, Jake?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Yes we are.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Antonio. No. Listen to me and don't argue.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: It's okay Tony. I'll see you tomorrow.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Goodnight, Jake.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Goodnight, Mrs. Calvelli.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: See you tomorrow.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Yeah, see you tomorrow.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: I'm not talking to my mother anymore.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: She said you can't come over to our place. It's not right.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Why doesn't she want me over?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: I don't think your father wants me around very much anymore either. He might be too chicken to come out and say it, but I can tell.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Why are they so mad at us?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Our parents are involved in a business matter and it's getting ugly. So they're taking it out on us.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: You're right. My dad was very cold to you.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: You'd think I was the enemy.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I won't talk to my parents either then.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Really. Not unless they apologize.

Speaker: umar
Dialogue: Tony! C'mon!! Are you playing or what?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: You sure you can handle it? It won't be easy.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Of course I can handle it.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: You're a great friend, Jake.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: You too.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Hey.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Did something happen with Leonor downstairs?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: The store is closed. It's not even five yet.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Have you seen Tony?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Jake, can you stop playing around for a second??

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Did you see if the store was open earlier when you got home?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Was it open?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: No? It wasn't?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Talk to me Jake!

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Audrey. Hi.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: It's not your fault.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: But I feel very responsible. We are responsible.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Audrey will tell you if she thinks you owe her money. Don't worry about it.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: She sort of did already.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: She told me we owe her money for the store.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Incredible.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Yes, I know.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Jake. Did you see Leonor today?

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Ah. Still not talking.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: You know, you can't go on with this forever.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Have you seen Jake's latest artwork?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: He's been doing a lot of mythological stuff.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Is that inspired by that book I gave you?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: The Blood of Olympus.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Truth is, if he's really serious about applying to LaGuardia, he's going to need to start preparing a serious portfolio, no?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Yes. From what I remember, only 2% of the students who apply to LaGuardia get accepted. This means two out of a hundred. Twenty out of a thousand. They're not just looking for talent; they're looking for serious commitment.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: And you famously flunked.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I didn't "flunk"!

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I wasn't accepted, which is different.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: bianca
Dialogue: Hi. Can I help you with anything?

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Thanks. I'm looking for Leonor. Oh, I see her.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Hi Leonor.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Hi. Just a second, let me just me finish this.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: You're home early.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Monday.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Right. Your day off. Oh, you have to see this new dress. Bianca, show her the new dress! The green one.

Speaker: bianca
Dialogue: Remember the original wrap dress, the first one that Diane von Furstenberg made?

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Of course. Wow, that's an original?

Speaker: bianca
Dialogue: No, we found this fabric, it's vintage fabric. And Leonor made the dress herself.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: It's beautiful. Wow. But it's really not my style. Thank you. I need to talk to Leonor.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Cute dress.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: I made it. The fabric is vintage.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Yes. I really like it, but I can't wear anything too tight on the waist these days. I need to lose a few pounds first.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Leonor, do you have a minute?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: I have to finish this for a client tonight.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Tony is still not talking?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: No. Not a word to me yesterday.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Same with Jake.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: It's very annoying.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: The one good thing, I have to say, is that Jake has been drawing and painting more than ever.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Is that good?

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Yes! If he really wants to apply to LaGuardia, he needs to prepare a portfolio. Is Tony still planning on applying also?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: How would I know? It's been four days and he hasn't said a word to me.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Listen, Leonor, you know that I'm trained in conflict resolution, so I'm hoping I can help here, help settle this problem between you and our family.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Oh really? Has your husband asked you to do that?

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: No. And by the way, he's been working really hard. I'm not sure you know that, but he's rehearsing for a new play.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: No. I haven't seen your husband.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: I know he's been waiting to hear from you.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Leonor?

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Can't we talk about what is really going on here?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Shh. Not here.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: I know you think we're the rich people coming into this neighborhood, but the truth is Brian hasn't made any money in years. I've been supporting this family with my hard work.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: That's not my problem.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: I know it's not. I'm just trying to talk about it.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: You think talking is going to solve all your problems, don't you? You think you can use some of your psychology class tricks and just wash away the dirt here? That dirt is my sweat, sweetie. It's my life. It's not going to be that easy.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: I know that. What I want to tell you is we will give you time, but we need this money. We need the shop to cover its rent. That's not an unfair thing to ask of a tenant.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: But I'm not a tenant. To Max I was more than a tenant. I was family. I belong here. And before you go any further; let me ask you: do you know how much work I've done here? The tile floors? The marble bathroom? That office in the back? I paid for all that.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: You look like you've been doing this acting thing forever.

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Like when you did the Emotional Recall exercise, it just seems so natural, I can't explain.

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: You know, my father was a stunt man when I was a kid. So I spent a lot of time on sets and stuff.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: So you have been doing this forever.

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: No, because when I was eight years old he died.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Did he die doing a stunt?

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: No! He had throat cancer.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Oh.  I'm sorry for your loss.

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: I'll see you later?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: I hope so.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Do you know anyone with a swimming pool?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: No, why?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: I would do anything to see her in a bikini. Can you imagine?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I never thought about that.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: So what about you? Who do you like?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: They're all very nice.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: You can tell me, you know.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Tell you what?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: If you like someone.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: That's what you always say.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Well I do have an idea you might like.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Eva talked about going dancing. There's a matinee club, like after hours, for kids.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: When is it?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Sunday afternoon, in the City.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Let's go!

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: It would be fun, right?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: That would be perfect. If I can just dance with her...

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Wow, that's getting good, Jake. I'm impressed.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Your father.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Tony! Whoa, man, watch out buddy.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Wait, wait. Let me do this for you. Don't worry. This is good luck. There you go. So tell me; what's going on? How's school? You still hoping for LaGuardia?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: C'mon, Antonio. You're not going to talk to your father?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Did the cat get your tongue?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: You forget he's too old for this kind of joke.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: What happened?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: He's mad at his mother.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: What about?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Ask him.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Tony, now that I'm here you're not going to say anything to me?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Go finish your homework, Antonio. We're having dinner soon.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: So what are you going to do, Leonor?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: I don't know yet, but Hernn is helping me out.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Hernn? Isn't he a bankruptcy lawyer?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Is he the best person for this?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: He's my friend. He knows strategy.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Are we talking about an exit strategy?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: No. A fighting strategy.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: But you should have an exit plan.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: I intend to fight. They can't do this to me.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: What if they can?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: What do you want me to say, Nick? That I'm going to open a drug store? Start making furniture?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Or look for a job?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: You can't be serious.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Don't take everything so personally, Leonor. The world isn't always stacked up against you.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: What does this have to do with anything?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Rent goes up. That's life in this city. These people are not doing this to you.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Why do you always have to disagree with me?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: I'm not disagreeing with you.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Can't you be on my side for once in your life?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: I'm just being realistic. Life here is expensive. I think you should have a plan.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: What do you think I'm doing? Do you think this is easy for me?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: I know it's not.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: That store is how I have raised our son. With not much help from you, thank you very much.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: That's not true.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Really? Do you think that sending him a little gift at the end of the year is enough to keep him fed? To buy him clothes? To take him to a movie every so often?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Can we not talk about money now? Damn, Leonor. You spoil everything. I can't even eat.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Can you keep a secret? Swear? I was invited to head the mission in Kinshasa. It's a nice big city for Africa.  Oh no. No! No!! Shit.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Not far from Angola. I'm finally going to have my own apartment. Why don't you come and stay with me for a while? We could go on a safari. The rainforest is incredible. They're famous for these big gorillas, hippopotamus, all kinds of animals.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: This acting school thing. Is it serious?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: How serious?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: That's good. There's a lot more in this world than Brooklyn.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Listen, Tony. I know your mom can be a little rough, but she's just worried about you. You're not a kid anymore, and she needs you to look out for her. I need you to look out for her.

Speaker: audrey
Dialogue: Well, Dad must have really liked her. That part I think she's probably right about. He never raised the rent on the store. Not even once in more than eight years. And now Leonor's lawyer is charging us for improvements she made in the store.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: What does that mean?

Speaker: audrey
Dialogue: She wants to fight. The woman is trouble, Brian. Once again, our warm, lovable, unwise father left us with a big mess, and no instructions.

Speaker: audrey
Dialogue: Is it terrible, Brian, that I don't really miss him?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: No, it's not terrible. It's sad, but I don't blame you.

Speaker: audrey
Dialogue: Do you miss him?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Sometimes. But I live in his house, so I probably think about him more than you do.

Speaker: audrey
Dialogue: She's claiming she has the right to stay paying almost nothing. I think we should start the eviction process as soon as possible.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I don't want to have to do that.

Speaker: audrey
Dialogue: It takes a while, you know.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I just don't want this to get ugly. The boys are best friends now.

Speaker: audrey
Dialogue: Remember that Dad worked very hard to leave us something. Now you have a nice big apartment, and I'm getting nothing.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Just give me a little more time.

Speaker: audrey
Dialogue: I can't do this without you, you know.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Hey, do you want to come with me to the beach?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: The beach! This summer! You want to come with me?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Yes? No?

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: No, Tony. You're really nice and everything..., but I'm into older guys.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Oh, okay. Thank you for being honest.

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Thank you for being honest.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Do you want some more?

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: How'd it go?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I think it's going to be great. I love my part, I love the actors, the play is fantastic.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: I'll toast to that.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: What's going on?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Did you see the sign Leonor has posted in the window?

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: No, I didn't see anything.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: She doesn't acknowledge the new lease, she doesn't try to negotiate and she has no plans of leaving. And now she's actually hiring new people, can you believe it?

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: I told you this wasn't going to be easy.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Audrey wants to start an eviction process. She has a lawyer ready to go already.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Good. Then it's decided.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Is it?

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Who's going to tell Jake?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I will. It's my problem.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Well then tell him soon. Please.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: He's just being so childish lately.

Speaker: nina
Dialogue: What are you writing?

Speaker: arkadina
Dialogue: Boris! Where are you?

Speaker: arkadina
Dialogue: We are not going away, after all.

Speaker: nina
Dialogue: It is a dream!

Speaker: roger
Dialogue: It's in your delivery. It's very natural. You really manage to make Trigorin feel contemporary.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Well, thank you, Roger.

Speaker: roger
Dialogue: He's like one of those famous artists we meet at a party, you know? You're excited at first, but the minute you start a conversation, you're begging not to be left alone with the guy.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Is that a good thing?

Speaker: roger
Dialogue: Yes!

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: He's such a tormented artist. It's wonderful.

Speaker: roger
Dialogue: And there were some really funny parts too.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Isn't it! Chekhov called it a comedy in four acts.

Speaker: roger
Dialogue: Act two, particularly.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: It is.

Speaker: roger
Dialogue: Bye Kathy. Great to see you.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Loved seeing you, Roger. It's been a great night.

Speaker: roger
Dialogue: Bye fellas. You should be very proud of this man here!

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: So?

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Jake? It's your dad's opening night.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Did you understand why Nina says she's the seagull?

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Brian. They're kids. To be honest, I'm not even sure I get that part.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: But that doesn't take anything away from the pleasure of the story.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Do either of you care about anyone other than yourselves?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Jake? Say something.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Say something!

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: One of the hardest things to realize as a child is that your parents are people too. Can you understand that? That they care about things. That they make mistakes. That they try to do what they think is right. Does any of what I'm saying make any sense to you?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: What's so funny, Tony? Why don't you tell me, what's funny?? You think being an actor is easy? You think you have it in you for one rejection after another? Let's see how you react when you don't get into LaGuardia. Let's just see then.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Brian...

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: God damn it!!

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Dresses go over there, on that rack on the left. Before you hang them, make sure they have a price tag. Also, try to arrange them by color, or tone. I usually like to start with lighter colors in the front, and end with darker ones. Black goes in the back. The women here like black a lot, so if they're looking for a little black dress, they might see a lot of other stuff before they get there.

Speaker: valentina
Dialogue: I see. So if they don't know what they want, I try to keep them here in the front first, and then show them the ones in the back.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Unless they ask specifically for black.

Speaker: valentina
Dialogue: Hello. Can I help you?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: It's okay, Valentina. It's for me. This is Brian Jardine, our neighbor. He's a great actor.

Speaker: valentina
Dialogue: Oh really? Have I seen you in anything?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I doubt it.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: He's in a new play. What is it called?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: The Seagull.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Oh. That must be very popular.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Can you give me five minutes alone? Please?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: The day your father died, he came by in the morning. I asked him to buy me a pack of cigarettes, and then I never saw him again.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Your father cared about me, Brian. Do you believe that? Every day we would talk, and we would share things with each other. Have you ever had a friend like that? Someone you could tell anything?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Only my wife. I'm a lot like Jake. I've never been good at having close friends.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I hope you can understand that what's happening is nothing personal.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: I can't afford to pay three times the rent I paid your father. It's not possible. I can't survive.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: I thought you were in a new big play.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I am in a new play. But it's not big, and it's not a lot of money. It's just the way it is, Leonor. I'm fortunate enough to have had a father who left me a house in Brooklyn.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: He wanted me to stay here. He told me so.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Leonor. I also have a sister, and she has her own family, and we all have to decide together what to do. It's not just up to me.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: You know your father thought your sister was the one who inherited his brains.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: They were very much alike. I'm sure he would agree with Audrey that, above everything, it's important to take care of business.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: No. He wouldn't have agreed. I can promise you that.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Leonor, what do you want me to say? I have a family. We have bills too.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Do you know why your father didn't go to your son's birthday party, the last one?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: He had the flu.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: No. That's maybe what he told you. The truth is, he was embarrassed, Brian. He was embarrassed that everything in your house was paid for by your wife. He thought you should be more of a man. He hated being around you.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Well, he's not around anymore, is he.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: He certainly isn't.

Speaker: hernn
Dialogue: This Holdover clause is common in any commercial lease.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: What am I going to do? I can't afford this.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Jesus! I told you to knock before you come in. What do you want?

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: I am so tired of you playing this silly game!

Speaker: hernn
Dialogue: I'm sorry, Leonor.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Where do they even get this number?

Speaker: hernn
Dialogue: The penalty for overstaying may seem like a high number, and it is. That's why it's in the contract; to prevent that the tenant overstays paying below the market rent indefinitely.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Isn't there anything else we can do?

Speaker: hernn
Dialogue: Leonor, I've done everything I can. It's over now. You have a week to leave the premises.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Don't worry, Mami. I'm going to help you. I promise, I'll figure out a way we can work it all out.  He holds her as her crying turns into sobs.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Hello, Mr. J. Is Jake home?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Yes, he's doing his homework.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: I'd like to talk to him if I could.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Of course, Tony. Come in.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Why don't you both come in. Leonor. Please.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: You sure I can't get you something, Leonor.

Speaker: leonor
Dialogue: Yes, I'm fine.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Mom! Dad! Mom!!

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: He talks! Jacob talks!

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Mom!!!

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: What's going on?!

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Mom, Tony told me Leonor is being evacuated from the store!

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: It's not an evacuation. It's an eviction.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: That's worse!

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: How could you do that? How could you do that to them? Dad??

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: It's a terrible situation.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: The rent is too expensive! She can't afford it, Mom. So Dad needs to give her a discount so she can!

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Your mother and I wanted to talk to you, Jake, but this not talking didn't help!

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Don't blame this on him.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: It's okay, I'm talking now! I'm sorry! I'm sorry! I'll never do that again. I promise. Dad, I promise.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Jake, calm down.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I have a great idea.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Let me explain to you, Jake. Grandpa Max left this house not just for the three of us here.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I know. He loved Leonor too. Tony told me!

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: He liked Leonor, of course, but he left the house for us, and also for Aunt Audrey.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: But I have an idea! I know how we can make it work! We go back to our old apartment, and we rent this place and give the money to Aunt Audrey. Tony and I are both going to be at the LaGuardia High School for Performing Arts in Manhattan, so I won't need to take the subway or anything to school. I can walk. And you'll be closer to the theater. I loved the show, Dad. I loved it. Tony did too. We both talked about it a lot afterwards. You were so good! And I thought it was really complex and everything. I'm sorry I didn't tell you then. I'm sorry. But I loved it. I really did!

Speaker: park ranger
Dialogue: Mr. Jardine?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: How are you, Son?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I'm sorry, Dad.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: What happened?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: There was a bump on the path...

Speaker: park ranger
Dialogue: We got a call from a woman who saw Jake here flying through the air and landing on the asphalt. When we found him, he couldn't move.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I'm better now.

Speaker: park ranger
Dialogue: He is better. But he probably shouldn't be on his own at his age.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: There was a bump, I didn't see.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Are you hurt?

Speaker: park ranger
Dialogue: He fell on his right side shoulder, and he scraped his knee.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Let's go home.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: Is it okay like this?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Yeah. Go slow.

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: And how's your arm? Can you move it okay?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: It hurts when I go like this.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Dad had a heating pad that he used to use. I can't find it.  You know where it is?

Speaker: kathy
Dialogue: I think it's in the hall closet. I'll get it in a minute.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Do you still have a lot to do to finish your portfolio?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I just need to finish one painting, and then I'm done.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: That's what you said last week. You just had to finish one painting.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I want them to be good.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Jake, do you by any chance remember that story I told you, about my friend Tina?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: The one who sold her hair in India for a train ticket?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: No, that was Martine. Tina was a girl I knew in high school who was a dancer. Her mother was a dancer. She was literally born to be a dancer. She had a perfect ballet dancer's body, and all of us were certain she was going to be a big success.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Have I seen her dance?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: No. During high school, she got into a really good conservatory, and I ran into her a couple of times after that, and she was always about to get this, or about to get that. But each time, her arm would be in a sling, or she would be on crutches. She would have a pulled ligament. Or a stress fracture in her back. The last time I saw her, I ran into her on the subway, it was clear she hadn't danced for years. She was fat. You would have never imagined that she was the same girl.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Gee, thanks Dad. That's a very encouraging story.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Why do you think Tina didn't go very far?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: She trained too hard. She practiced too much. She didn't trust her own natural abilities.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Jake, you're going to meet a lot of really talented people in your life. But they won't all be suited to be artists, they won't all have the brains to know when to insist, and when to stop. When to push yourself, and when to relax. Most of them won't have that balance.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: And how do I know if I have the balance?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: That's why I'm telling you this, because you'll turn in your portfolio soon, and they're going to love it. They're going to love you. I know they will. You'll go to LaGuardia, and you'll have fun, but also plenty of challenges. Soon enough you'll find out if you have the balance.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: There you go. Do you know if Tony got in?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I don't know. I don't know what he's doing.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Son. I wish I'd done things differently.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: With Tony, and his mother. I wish I had told you earlier what was going on.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Would it have changed anything?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: No, probably not. But still.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Dad, would you mind if I give you some advice? Would that be okay.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Please.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Don't worry so much.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: That's all.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: That's a lot.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Dad, would you mind if I play one of my video games? I know it's Tuesday, and I know I should do something more productive with my time, but I'm kind of tired.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Of course, Son.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Will Mom be mad?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I don't think so.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Yours looks different too.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: I went to Africa to visit my dad.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: How was it?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Amazing.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: And how's your mom?

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: She's busy. She's a real estate agent now.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: You could've sent me an email from Africa.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: You know me. I'm not much of a writer...

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I love that necklace.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Thanks. They make these for tourists, they don't really wear them there. But I like it too.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Hey, you should come meet my buddies from school.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Did you get into LaGuardia?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: I did.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: That's awesome!

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: There's this girl in my class, her mother is on Broadway, she can act better than anyone I know.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Gee, thanks.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: We should all go out together sometime.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: Sure, but I met this girl in Kinshasa, and my heart belongs to her. Do you want to see a picture?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: She's a really good kisser. She's going to come to visit soon.

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: Cool.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: And you, have you kissed anyone yet?

Speaker: jake
Dialogue: No, but I've met someone.  You'll meet him.

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: You know! Finally, you know!

Speaker: tony
Dialogue: I'm here with a friend from Congo. Let's go find him. He's teaching me French, and I help him with his English - he says "bitchful", like... "This sculpture is so `bitchful'".
